question: B 03 (b)
sols_html:
Recall that a matrix is invertible if and only if its determinant, det(A) \(\neq\) 0. Also recall that the determinant of a matrix is the product of its eigenvalues. In part(a), we deduced that the eigenvalues were \(\lambda_1=2\) and \(\lambda_2=0\). Therefore we have that,

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle{}\textrm{det}(A)=\lambda_1\lambda_2=2(0)=0.\end{aligned}\]

Therefore we conclude that det(A)=0 and thus that the matrix A is not invertible.

statement_html:
Let A be a \(2\times{2}\) matrix which transforms

\[\begin{aligned} \begin{bmatrix} 1\\ 1 \end{bmatrix} \quad \text{to} \quad \begin{bmatrix} 2\\ 2 \end{bmatrix}\end{aligned}\]

and transforms

\[\begin{aligned} \begin{bmatrix} 1\\ -1 \end{bmatrix} \quad \text{to} \quad \begin{bmatrix} 0\\ 0 \end{bmatrix}.\end{aligned}\]

Is A invertible? Justify briefly.
